questions.text: The tumor cells as shown in the image are seen in:
questions.solution:
The cells shown in the slide are cloverleaf or flower cells with multilobulated nuclei that are frequently observed in adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma.

Adult T-cell leukemia/ lymphoma occurs in adults infected by human T-cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1). It is a neoplasm of CD4+ cells and is a rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to 1 year.

Common findings include skin lesions, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly and hypercalcemia.

Peripheral smear blood shows characteristic cloverleaf cells or flower cells which are tumour cells with multilobulated nuclei. Lymphocytosis is also observed.

Other options:

Mantle cell lymphoma is a type of Non-Hodgkin lymphoma in which the proliferation consists of a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft (cleaved) nuclear contours. 

Peripheral T cell lymphoma is composed of malignant T cells of varied sizes with infiltration of reactive cells, such as eosinophils and macrophages. 

Anaplastic large cell lymphoma occurs due to mutation in ALK gene. It consists of large anaplastic cells with horseshoe-shaped nuclei and spacious cytoplasm (hallmark cells). 

Related Pearl: Infectious Agents Associated with the Development of Lymphoid Malignancies

questions.text: Seen below is the microscopic appearance of a liver biopsy section. Which of the following is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
The above slide is of hereditary hemochromatosis which is an autosomal recessive condition.

The liver biopsy section stained with Perl's Prussian Blue shows blue stained hepatocyte iron accumulation.

Hemochromatosis is caused by excessive iron absorption, most of which is deposited in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas, followed by heart, joints, and endocrine organs.

  • When hemochromatosis results from an inherited disorder, it is referred to as hereditary hemochromatosis.
  • When accumulation occurs as a consequence of parenteral administration of iron- secondary hemochromatosis.
  • Total body iron pool ranges from 2 to 6 gm in normal adults; about 0.5 gm is stored in the liver, 98% of which is in hepatocytes.
  • The following features characterize severe iron overload in the body:
    • Micronodular cirrhosis
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Abnormal skin pigmentation
  • Iron accumulation in hereditary forms is lifelong but the injury caused by excessive iron is slow and progressive; hence symptoms usually first appear in the fourth to fifth decades of life in men and later in women
  • In hereditary hemochromatosis, regulation of intestinal absorption of dietary iron is abnormal, leading to net iron accumulation of 0.5 to 1 gm/year.
  • The main regulator of iron absorption is the protein hepcidin, encoded by the HAMP gene and secreted by the liver
  • Other proteins involved in iron metabolism, do so by regulating hepcidin levels. These include
    • Hemojuvelin (HJV)
    • Transferrin receptor 2 (TFR2)
    • HFE, the product of the hemochromatosis gene.
  • Decreased hepcidin synthesis has a central role in the pathogenesis of hemochromatosis.
  • The adult form of hemochromatosis is almost always caused by mutations of HFE; mutation of TFR2 is far less common.
  • Mutations in HAMP and HJV cause severe juvenile hemochromatosis
  • Manifestations
    • Deposition of hemosiderin in the following organs (in decreasing order of severity) the liver, pancreas, myocardium, pituitary gland, adrenal gland, thyroid and parathyroid glands, joints, and skin;
    • Cirrhosis; and
    • Pancreatic fibrosis.
  • Liver -Golden-yellow hemosiderin granules in the cytoplasm of periportal hepatocytes that stain with Prussian blue small, shrunken liver with a micronodular pattern of cirrhosis.
  • Biochemical determination of hepatic tissue iron concentration has been the gold standard for quantitating hepatic iron
  • The therapy of hemochromatosis involves removal of the excess body iron, best accomplished by weekly or twice-weekly phlebotomy of 500 mL (200–250 mg of iron).
  • Chelating agents such as desferoxamine, when given parenterally, remove 10–20 mg of iron per day, which is much less than that
    mobilized by once-weekly phlebotomy.
  • Death may result from cirrhosis or cardiac disease.
  • A significant cause of death is hepatocellular carcinomas.

Related Pearl: Classification of Iron Overload

 Primary / Hereditary Hemochromatosis

HFE gene-related

  • Type 1: C282Y mutations of genes encoding HFE 

Non-HFE gene-related

  • Type 2: Juvenile hemochromatosis
    • 2a - HJV mutation (hemojuvelin)
    • 2b - HAMP mutation (Hepcidin)
  • Type 3: Transferrin receptor 2 (TfR2) related 
  • Type 4: Ferroportin-related HH 

Secondary / Acquired Hemochromatosis

Transfusion iron overload

  • Thalassemia major
  • Sideroblastic anemia
  • Chronic hemolytic anemias

Chronic liver disease

  • Alcoholic liver disease
  • Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda

Miscellaneous

  • Congenital atransferrinemia
  • African iron overload (Bantu siderosis)

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue, weight loss, and heaviness in the left hypochondrium for 6 months. His hemogram and peripheral smear are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb - 10 gm/dL

TLC - 5.5 lakhs/mm3

Platelet count - 4 lakhs/mm3
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). 

In this condition, the peripheral smear contains neutrophils and their precursors of various sizes and configurations like band cells, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and blasts. Hence, the histological picture is described to have garden party or college girl appearance. 

The image given below shows the peripheral smear in CML showing garden party or college girl appearance.

CML is a myeloproliferative disorder with peak incidence in the 5th to 6th decades of life. It occurs due to the chimeric BCR-ABL gene.

Clinical features of CML:

  • Hypermetabolism
  • Fatigability
  • Weakness
  • Weight loss and anorexia
  • Extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis causing -
    • Splenomegaly
    • Mild hepatomegaly
    • Lymphadenopathy

Hematological findings include:

  • Mild-to-moderate anemia 
  • Leukocytosis
  • Platelets - usually increased
  • DLC shows predominantly neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils and blasts (>10%) 

Note: Convent girl appearance is seen in CLL.

questions.text: The images below display the gross and microscopic features of a brain tumour in a child. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gross features (cystic tumor) and microscopy (microcystic and fibrillary areas) suggest pilocytic astrocytoma.

Pilocytic astrocytomas typically occur in children and young adults. It is located in the cerebellum, floor, and walls of the third ventricle, the optic nerves, and cerebral hemispheres. It is often cystic. Tumors are often biphasic, with both loose microcystic and fibrillary areas. Bipolar cells with long, thin “hairlike” processes that are GFAP-positive and form dense fibrillary meshwork are seen.

Rosenthal fibers and eosinophilic granular bodies are characteristic findings. Necrosis and brisk mitotic activity are uncommon.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with weight loss, fever, and a painless swelling in the area of his jaw. CBC reveals anaemia and lymphocytosis. Biopsy findings from the swelling are shown in the image below. Which of the following is not true about this patient’s condition?

choices.text: All forms of this tumour are associated with translocations of the MYC gene
Endemic  forms are latently infected with EBV
Tumor exhibits a high mitotic index
Neoplastic cells are usually BCL2 positive

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and biopsy findings point to a diagnosis of Burkitt's lymphoma. Neoplastic cells in Burkitt's lymphoma are usually BCL2 negative.

The biopsy image shows the classical finding of Burkitt's lymphoma called the starry sky appearance.

Tumour cells show multiple small nucleoli, minimal cytoplasm and a high mitotic index. They are closely apposed to each other forming a dark blue background (sky).

The macrophages get stuffed in between along with cellular debris. They are called tingible body macrophages. Upon fixation, the cytoplasm of these phagocytes washes away leaving behind white spaces filled with debris (the stars).

Burkitt lymphoma is the most common NHL in children <15 years.

Three distinct clinical forms of Burkitt's lymphoma are:

  • Endemic- affects children in Africa, affects jaw, maxilla, and is EBV-associated.
  • Sporadic- in adults in western countries.
  • Immunodeficiency associated- is associated with HIV infection.

It is the most rapidly proliferating human tumor, Ki-67 stains for 100% of cells (DLBCL- 40% staining with Ki-67). Histology shows the characteristic starry sky pattern.

Immunophenotypic markers include:

  • Surface IgM type and immunoglobulin light chains (kappa > lambda)
  • B cell-associated antigens -CD19, CD20, CD22, CD79a
  • Germinal centre-associated markers- CD10 & BCL-6
  • HLA-DR and CD43
  • Expression of CD21 -the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)/C3d receptor, is dependent on the EBV status of the tumors
    • Endemic BL: EBV (+), express CD21
    • Non-endemic BL: EBV (--) and lack CD21 expression

Treatment must begin within 48h of diagnosis in both children and adults with an intensive combination of chemotherapy regimens with high doses of cyclophosphamide and CNS prophylaxis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with a worsening headache for 8 months. A left sub frontal mass is resected. Microscopy is as seen below and tumor cells express progesterone receptors.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Microscopy shows a tumor with meningothelial whorls, syncytial cells with indistinct cell membranes and psammoma bodies. Most likely diagnosis is a meningioma.

Meningioma: They are predominantly benign tumors of adults, usually attached to the dura, that arise from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid.

  • Meningiomas may be found along any of the external surfaces of the brain as well as within the ventricular system, where they arise from the stromal arachnoid cells of the choroid plexus.
  • Prior radiation therapy to the head and neck, typically is a risk factor.
  • The most common cytogenetic abnormality is loss of chromosome 22, especially the long arm (22q).
  • Meningiomas are a common lesion in the setting of NF2 (multiple sites, especially in association with acoustic neuromas or glial tumors.
  • The surface of the mass is usually encapsulated.
  • They may also grow en plaque, in which the tumor spreads in a sheetlike fashion along the surface of the dura. This form is commonly associated with hyperostotic reactive changes in the adjacent bone.
  • The lesions may contain numerous calcified psammoma bodies.

Histological subtypes:

  • WHO Grade I – Menigothelial, fibroblastic, transitional, psammomatous, secretory, microcystic
  • WHO Grade II- Clear cell, chordoid, atypical
  • Grade III – Papillary, rhabdoid, anaplastic
  • Atypical meningiomas (WHO grade II/IV) - a higher rate of recurrence and more aggressive local growth
  • Anaplastic (malignant) meningioma (WHO grade III/IV) - highly aggressive tumor with the appearance of a high-grade sarcoma
  • Immunoreactive for epithelial membrane antigen
  • Keratin is restricted to lesions with the secretory pattern, and these tumors are also positive for carcinoembryonic antigen
  • Moderate (3: 2) female predominance, usually solitary, but when present at multiple sites, the possibility of neurofibromatosis type 2 should be considered.
  • Meningiomas often express progesterone receptors and may grow more rapidly during pregnancy.

questions.text: During the autopsy of a 90-year-old woman, a normal-looking liver was noted. The following microscopic appearance of hepatocytes was noted. Which of the following cellular mechanisms is likely responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
The given image shows brownish lipofuscin granules within the liver cells. It is composed of lipid-containing residues of lysosomal digestion that are formed due to autophagocytosis.

Lipofuscin is a wear-and-tear pigment that is due to free radical injury to the tissue. It is prominent in the liver and heart of aging patients or patients with severe malnutrition and cancer cachexia.

Autophagy is a process by which the cell consumes itself. It involves the sequestration of cellular organelles into cytoplasmic autophagic vacuoles (autophagosomes) that fuse with lysosomes, resulting in the digestion of the enclosed material. It occurs in the following conditions:

  • As a survival mechanism during nutrient deprivation and stress conditions
  • Cancers, inflammatory bowel diseases, neurodegenerative disorders - due to dysregulation

questions.text: The finding of the immunohistochemistry studies of a patient with a neurodegenerative disease is given below. Identify the structure marked in the image.
questions.solution:
The given image is the histological sample of the substantia nigra showing neurons with a Lewy body, extracellular neuromelanin, and pigment-laden macrophages n Parkinson's disease. 

Lewy bodies are single or multiple intracytoplasmic, round to elongated, eosinophilic inclusions that often have a dense core surrounded by a pale halo. Accumulations of these are seen in subcortical regions (basal ganglia, striatum, locus coeruleus, substantia nigra, thalamus) as well as the cerebral cortex. Lewy bodies are aggregates of insoluble fibrillar proteins called alpha-synuclein (specific) and ubiquitin in the neural cells. They are typically seen in Parkinson's disease, Lewy body dementia, and a few variants of Alzheimer's disease. They mainly disrupt the excitatory dopaminergic pathways.

 Other options:

Pick bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, weakly basophilic filamentous inclusions that stain strongly with silver methods. It contains 3R tau and is seen in frontotemporal lobar degeneration.

 

Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions found in pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. They are pathognomonic microscopic findings seen in rabies.

 

Lafora bodies are seen in the cytoplasm of neurons in myoclonic epilepsy. Lafora bodies are aggregates of polyglucosans, poorly constructed glycogen molecules with inordinately long strands that render them insoluble.

Related Pearl: Pathological Named Bodies

Bodies Found in
Asteroid bodies Sarcoidosis, Sporotrichosis

Related Pearl: Synucleinopathies and tauopathies

Synucleinopathies:
  • Parkinson’s disease
  • Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Multiple system atrophy
  • REM behavioral disorder
  • Pure autonomic failure 
Tauopathies:
  • Alzheimer’s disease
  • Down syndrome
  • Progressive supranuclear palsy
  • Corticobasal degeneration
  • Pick’s disease/frontotemporal dementia
  • Chronic traumatic encephalopathy/punch drunk syndrome/dementia pugilistica
  • Postencephalitic parkinsonism
  • Pantothenate kinase-associated degeneration
  • Niemann Pick disease type C
  • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with lymphoma. The microscopic picture is as given below. The cells seen in the image should be _______
questions.solution:
Following image shows Reed-Sternberg cell, lymphohistiocytic variant (multiple infolded nuclear membranes, small nucleoli, fine chromatin, and abundant pale cytoplasm). It is seen in lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin’s lymphoma which is CD20+ and BCL-6+.

The WHO classification recognizes five subtypes of HL:

1. Nodular sclerosis
2. Mixed cellularity
3. Lymphocyte-rich
4. Lymphocyte depletion
5. Lymphocyte predominance

In the first four subtypes—nodular sclerosis, mixed cellularity, lymphocyte-rich, and lymphocyte depletion—the Reed-Sternberg cells have a similar immunophenotype (CD15+ and CD30+). These subtypes are often lumped together as classical forms of HL.

In lymphocyte predominance subtype, the Reed-Sternberg cells have a distinctive B-cell immunophenotype (CD20+ and BCL-6+ and are negative for CD15 and CD30). Hence it is called non classical hodgkin’s lymphoma.

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Classic subtypes

  • Nodular sclerosis 
  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

  • Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence.

questions.text: The given image is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of Heinz bodies and bite cells suggestive of Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency.

In Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, after oxidant drug exposure, the peripheral blood smear shows red cells with precipitates of denatured globin which are known as Heinz bodies. 

As the splenic macrophages pluck out these inclusions, bite cells similar to the one in this smear are produced.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with bloody nasal discharge, orbital swelling, and pain. The culture of Periorbital pus showed the following appearance. The most probable organism is
questions.solution:
The image shows septate hyphae showing dichotomous branching with typical conidiophore seen in microscopy which is characteristic of aspergillus infection.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: The given egg is of:
questions.solution:
Given egg is elongated with lateral spine. Hence it is an egg of Schistosoma mansoni.

Species differentiation of Schistosoma can be done based on the location of spine as follows.

  • Terminal spine: Schistosoma hematobium
  • Lateral spine: Schistosoma mansoni
  • Round with small lateral knob or Rudimentary spine: Schistosoma japonicum.

Related Pearl: Eggs of Schistosoma

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presents with dry eyes,  dry mouth, and difficulty swallowing solid food. Examination reveals enlargement of parotid glands and dryness of buccal mucosa. Laboratory examination shows the presence of both SS-A and SS-B antibodies. The histopathological image of the salivary gland is given below. All are true about this condition, except ______.

choices.text: About 75% of patients have rheumatoid factor
Patients are at high risk for development of B-cell lymphomas
Lacrimal and salivary glands are mainly involved

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is a 55-year-old female patient with dry eyes, dry mouth, difficulty swallowing solid food, and the findings such as enlarged parotid gland, dry buccal mucosa, and antibodies positive for SS-A and SS-B is Sjogren's syndrome.  The histopathology shows the focal lymphoplasmacytic infiltration in the minor salivary gland. Glomerular lesions are extremely rare in Sjögren syndrome.

Sjögren's syndrome is a chronic disease wherein the lacrimal and salivary glands undergo immunologically-mediated destruction. This leads to the characteristic features of dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia). It can manifest as primary or secondary. Primary is an isolated form known as sicca syndrome. It is characterized by decreased tears and saliva. The salivary glands and lacrimal glands get infiltrated with lymphocytes and undergo fibrosis. The secondary form is associated with other autoimmune disorders. 

Clinically, it is more common in women between 50-60 years. They present with a blurring of vision, burning, itching of the eyes, difficulty swallowing solid foods, dryness of the buccal mucosa, and parotid gland enlargement. 

Antibodies directed against two ribonucleoprotein antigens- SS-A (Ro) and SS-B (La) are detected in almost all patients with Sjogren's syndrome. Rheumatoid factor is seen in about 75% of the patients. ANA is also often detected on immunofluorescence assay. A labial biopsy is useful and histology of salivary glands shows lymphocytic infiltration. 

Patients are at high risk for the development of B-cell lymphomas.

Related Pearl: Extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome

The extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are as follows:

  • Non-specific
    • Arthralgia or arthritis - It is the most common extraglandular manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jacoud’s arthropathy
    • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Accumulation of peri-epithelial lymphocytes
    • Interstitial lung disease - Most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
    • Renal tubular acidosis - Distal (type 1) RTA
    • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Immune complex-mediated
    • Small vessel vasculitis - Presents as cutaneous palpable purpura
    • Glomerulonephritis with cryoglobulinemia
    • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Lymphoma
    • Extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue (MALToma).

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and diarrhea. The given trophozoite stage is found in the stool sample. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the trophozoite stage of Balantidium coli. It is the only ciliated pathogenic protozoa infecting humans and is present in the large intestine as a commensal. It is the largest protozoan parasite of humans.

Trophozoite:

  • Large ovoid cell enclosed within a delicate pellicle showing longitudinal striations.
  • Has a narrow anterior end and a broad posterior end.
  • The cell has 2 nuclei—a large kidney-shaped macronucleus and a small micronucleus lying in its concavity.
  • 1 or 2 contractile vacuoles and several food vacuoles are present in the cytoplasm
  • There is a groove (peristome) at the anterior end that leads to the mouth (cytostome), and a short funnelshaped gullet (cytopharynx).
  • A small anal pore (cytopyge) is present posteriorly.
  • The cilia around the mouth are larger (adoral cilia)
  • Lives in the large intestine and feeds on cell debris, bacteria, starch grains, and other particles.
  • The trophozoite is actively motile due to the presence of short delicate cilia over the entire surface of the body. The invasive stage of the parasite is found in dysenteric stool.

Cyst:

  • It is spherical and measures 40–60 μm in diameter
  • A thick and transparent double-layered wall surrounds it
  • The cytoplasm is granular and has the macronucleus, micronucleus, and vacuoles present.
  • The cyst is the infective stage of B. coli and is found in chronic cases and carriers.

Balantidiasis is a zoonosis that is mostly asymptomatic. Pigs are the definitive hosts and man is an accidental host. Symptomatic disease presents with diarrhea or dysentery. The presence of intestinal ulcers and submucosal abscesses resembles amoebiasis.

The following image shows the trophozoite form of the Balantidum coli.

questions.text: A young man presented with hypertensive episodes, bloody stools and cutaneous nodules. He has a past history of hepatitis B infection. Vasculitis was suspected and a biopsy of the vessel was done. The histopathology of the tissue from the vessel is shown below. Identify the type of necrosis.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of polyarteritis nodosa and the above image depicts fibrinoid necrosis. It is seen in vasculitis like polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) in which the small and medium-sized blood vessels are affected as a result of immune complex deposition.

Polyarteritis nodosa is a medium and small-sized vessel vasculitis typically affecting the renal and visceral arteries, sparing pulmonary vessels. Patients present with variable symptoms including accelerated hypertension, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding, myalgias and cutaneous nodules. It is often associated with chronic hepatitis B infection, which causes the HBsAg-HbsAb complexes to deposit in affected vessels. Clinical manifestations are a result of ischemia and infarction of organs and tissues that are affected.

The diagnosis is based on the histopathological findings seen on a biopsy of the involved organs. Diagnosis can also be made by the demonstration of aneurysms of small and medium-sized arteries in the renal, hepatic, and visceral vasculature. 

Fibrinoid necrosis occurs in blood vessels in which the antigen-antibody complexes get deposited in the blood vessel walls. These complexes elicit an immune reaction leading to cell injury and leakage of fibrin and plasma proteins around the blood vessel and giving a circumferential pinkish appearance of necrosis. 

It is treated with immunosuppressive agents and has a high risk of mortality if left untreated.

The image below shows fibrinoid necrosis with intraluminal thrombosis in an artery of a patient with polyarteritis nodosa. 

Necrosis refers to irreversible cell death caused by the denaturation of proteins and enzymatic digestion of the injured cells. 

Gangrenous necrosis commonly occurs in the lower limbs due to decreased blood supply. This type of necrosis is usually coagulative necrosis and is called dry gangrene.

When this becomes superimposed with bacterial infection the harmful enzymes from the bacteria and inflammatory cells result in liquefactive necrosis which is called wet gangrene.

Caseous necrosis (cheese like) refers to a friable yellow white area of necrosis as seen in this image

  • On microscopic examination, the necrotic focus appears as a collection of fragmented or lysed cells with an amorphous granular pink appearance surrounded by inflammatory cells called as granuloma and is classical of tuberculosis as shown below.

Fat necrosis refers to the localised destruction of fat by pancreatic enzymes. The commonest cause of this type of necrosis is acute pancreatitis. In acute pancreatitis, these enzymes are released within or around the pancreas breaking down the triglycerides into fatty acids. When calcium binds to fatty acid it results in fat saponification giving a chalky white appearance.

Polyarteritis nodosa is a medium and small-sized vessel vasculitis typically affecting the renal and visceral arteries. Patients present with variable symptoms including accelerated hypertension, abdominal pain, gastrointestinal bleeding, myalgias and cutaneous nodules. It is often associated with chronic hepatitis B infection. Histology shows characteristic fibrinoid necrosis of the vessel wall with intraluminal thrombosis. This condition is treated with immunosuppressive agents and has a high risk of mortality. 

Related Pearl: Necrosis vs Apoptosis

Feature

Necrosis

Apoptosis

Active process
Physiologic or pathologic role

Invariably pathologic

Cell size

Enlarged (swelling)

Reduced (shrinkage)

Cells affected

Single cell death

Nucleus

Pyknosis →karyorrhexis →karyolysis

Fragmentation into nucleosome-size fragments

Plasma membrane

Disrupted

Intact; altered structure

Cellular contents

Enzymatic digestion; may leak out of cell

Intact; may be released in apoptotic bodies

Inflammation

Present

Absent

Marker

Annexin V

PAGE (DNA electrophoresis)

Step-ladder pattern

Related Pearl: Important Vasculitis with Features

Vasculitis

(Large vessel vasculitis)

Temporal, vertebral and ophthalmic arteries, aorta

Lymphocytes, and macrophages

>40 years old, polymyalgia rheumatica, granulomas, giant cells

(Large vessel vasculitis)

(Medium-sized and large arteries) Aortic arch, great vessels, pulmonary artery, coronary and renal arteries

Lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils, granulomas, giant cells

Small or medium-sized muscular arteries, typically involving renal and visceral vessels

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Spares pulmonary vessels, 30% of patients with  chronic hepatitis B

Neutrophils, eosinophils, and mononuclear cells,

Necrotizing glomerulonephritism (90% of patients) and pulmonary capillaritis leukocytoclastic vasculitis

Eosinophils (required), lymphocytes, macrophages, neutrophils

Associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, lung infiltrates, peripheral hypereosinophilia, and extravascular necrotizing granulomata.

questions.text: Histopathology of a patient who had pulmonary edema shows the following. The cells seen within the alveolar spaces are:
questions.solution:
• Heart failure cells are hemosiderin-laden macrophages.
  • In cardiac failure, red cells and plasma proteins extravasate into the edema fluid within the alveolar spaces, where they are phagocytosed and digested by macrophages, which store the iron recovered from hemoglobin in the form of hemosiderin.
  • These hemosiderin-laden macrophages (also known as heart failure cells) are telltale signs of previous episodes of pulmonary edema.

questions.text: Following copper penny bodies are feature of
questions.solution: Sclerotic bodies (Copper penny/Medler bodies) are features of Chromoblastomycosis also known as Fonseca’s disease or Pedroso’s disease or verrucous dermatitis.

questions.text: Identify the condition where the cells marked in the image is seen:
questions.solution:
The slide shows Anitschkow cells or caterpillar cells which are pathognomic for RF.

  • During acute rheumatic fever, focal inflammatory lesions are found in various tissues.
  • Distinctive lesions in the heart - Aschoff bodies, consisting of foci of T lymphocytes, occasional plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells (pathognomonic for RF)
  • These Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei (occasionally binucleate) in which the chromatin condenses into a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence the designation “caterpillar cells”)

 

Histology showing Aschoff bodies with Anitschkow cells in Rheumatic heart disease.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes with multiple circular, dry, scaly, itchy lesions on the scalp.  On further examination, it is seen that hair is involved but nails are spared. Scrapings from the lesion are inoculated and examined microscopically. Identify the dermatophyte based on the macroconidia seen in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of tinea capitis and the image showing large spindle-shaped macroconidia is a feature of Microsporum.

Dermatophytosis (commonly called tinea or ringworm) refers to infection of keratinized structures (the skin, hair, and nails) caused by a group of keratinophilic fungi, called the dermatophytes.

Dermatophytes are classified into 3 types:

  • Trichophyton infects skin, hair, and nails. The species include T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, T. violaceum, etc. Microconidia > Macroconidia
  • Microsporum infects only hair and skin but, not the nails. The species include M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. Macroconidia> Microconidia.
  • Epidermophyton infects only skin and nails, not hair. Floccosum is the only species in this genus. Only Macroconidia.

Clinical features of infection by Microsporum include:

  • Skin lesions in the skin tend to be circular, dry, erythematous, scaly, and itchy.
  • Hair lesions include kerion, scarring, and alopecia.

Diagnosis is established by clinical features, the use of Wood's lamp, and laboratory investigations such as microscopic examination and culture characteristics.

Microscopic examination of material teased out from the fungal colony (culture mount) or material taken on cellotape (cellotape mount) is observed for identification of the species. It is observed for the presence and type of hyphae and conidia. Conidia (asexual spores) are of two types: small unicellular microconidia and larger septate macroconidia.

Related Pearl: Characteristic features of macroconidia and microconidia of dermatophytes

Dermatophyte  

Macroconidia

Microconidia

Trichophyton

Thin-walled, pencil-shaped

Small unicellular

Microsporum

Multicellular, spindle-shaped

Scanty

Epidermophyton

Multicellular, pear-shaped, arranged in clusters

Absent

Trichophyton

 

Microsporum

 

Epidermophyton

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: brilliant green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum)

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Pityriasis versicolor

Faint yellow

Pseudomonas

Green

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

Porphyria

Urine, feces, blister fluid fluoresce red or pink

Vitiligo

Ivory or milky white

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented to the gynecology OPD with a history of abdominal pain and distension of abdomen. Ultrasound imaging revealed tumor in the right ovary. Serum level of inhibin was raised. The histopathology of the tumor is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology showing Call-Exner bodies are suggestive of granulosa cell tumor.

Call-Exner bodies are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material resembling immature follicles. Additionally, small, cuboidal to polygonal cells are seen which may grow in anastomosing cords, sheets, or strands. 

Granulosa cell tumors are composed of cells that resemble granulosa cells of a developing ovarian follicle. It can be of adult and juvenile types. Elevated tissue and serum levels of inhibin, a product of granulosa cells, are associated with this tumor.

Mutations of the FOXL2 gene are seen in most adult granulosa cell tumors.

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

questions.text: The below given image shows result of hair perforation test. The organism likely to show below given appearance is
questions.solution:
Image shows surface erosion of shaft caused by Trichophyton mentagrophytes.

Hair perforation test:

  • Done to differentiate Trichophyton rubrum from mentagrophytes.
  • A few strands of human hair are placed in a Petri dish with 20 ml of distilled water and autoclaved.
  • A few drops of sterile 10% yeast extract and a few fragments of the test fungus are added to the hair strands.
  • Incubated at 250C for 2-3 weeks.
  • Hair is removed and examined microscopically in a lactophenol cotton blue stained wet preparation.
  • T.mentagrophytes causes surface erosion of the shaft resulting in wedge shaped appearance of the shaft.

questions.text: 10 year old child presents with bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. Lymph node biopsy was performed, which shows cells as in the given figure. Which of the following is true regarding the condition?

choices.text: Hodgkin lymphoma; EBV and embryo cell
Non-Hodgkin lymphoma; HIV and giant B cell
Hodgkin lymphoma; EBV and Reed Sternberg cell

questions.solution: The sine qua non (an essential condition) of Hodgkin lymphoma is the Reed-Sternberg (RS) cell, a very large cell (15 to 45 μm in diameter) with an enormous multilobate nucleus, exceptionally prominent nucleoli, and abundant, usually slightly eosinophilic, cytoplasm. Particularly characteristic are cells with two mirror image nuclei or nuclear lobes, each containing a large (inclusion-like) acidophilic nucleolus surrounded by a clear zone, features that impart an owl-eye appearance.

questions.text: False statement about the organism shown in the image given below is
questions.solution:
The above image shows Trichomonas. It has no cystic stage.

Identification features of Trichomonas vaginalis:

  • Pear-shaped or ovoid
  • Short undulating membrane reaching upto the middle of the body
  • It has four anterior flagella and fifth running along the outer margin of the undulating membrane, which is supported at its base by a flexible rod, costa
  • A prominent axostyle runs throughout the length of the body and projects posteriorly like a tail
  • The cytoplasm shows prominent siderophillic granules, which are most numerous alongside the axostyle and costa
  • Jerky or twitching type of mobility

The below image shows: 1-anterior flagella, 2-kinetosomes, 3-parabasal body, 4-costa, 5-parabasal fibers, 6-undulating membrane, 7-posterior flagellum, 8-hydrogenosomes, 9-axostyle, 10-nucleus, 11-pelta.

Obligate parasite - Organism cannot survive outside host

  • No cystic stage. Trophozoites are infective forms
  • Sexual transmission is the main route of infection. Other modes are fomites, babies during passage through infected birth canal
  • Affects squamous epithelium - Intracellular edema and so called chicken-like epithelium, is the most characteristic feature of trichomoniasis
  • Habitat: Vagina and cervix in female and urethra in males
  • Clinical features: Often asymptomatic in males. In females, it leads to pruritic vaginitis with greenish yellow discharge, strawberry mucosa and dysuria
  • Diagnosis: By wet mount microscopy of vaginal or urethral discharge, Culture (gold standard - Cysteine-peptone-liver-maltose (CPLM) medium and plastic envelope medium (PEM)), PCR, and by demonstration of antigen in vaginal smear by ELISA
  • Treatment: Metronidazole is the drug of choice and simultaneous treatment of both partners is recommended

questions.text: The appearance of fibers in the histological image below is commonly seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Rosenthal fibers, which are commonly associated with pilocytic astrocytoma.

A Rosenthal fiber is a thick, elongated, worm-like, or "corkscrew" eosinophilic bundle that is found on H&E staining of the brain in the presence of long-standing gliosis, occasional tumors, and some metabolic disorders. It is usually associated with pilocytic astrocytoma (more common) or Alexander's disease (a rare leukodystrophy).

Pilocytic astrocytoma:

  • Pilocytic astrocytoma or juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma or cystic cerebellar astrocytoma is a brain tumor that occurs more often in children and young adults (in the first 20 years of life).
  • These tumors are usually slow-growing and benign. The neoplasms are associated with the formation of a single (or multiple) cyst(s) and can become very large.
  • Diagnosis can be made on the basis of brain MRI findings. Surgery is usually the treatment of choice. Total resection is often possible.

questions.text: The following image shows:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a sheathed microfilaria with 2 nuclei at the tail which is characteristic of Brugia malayi.

Brugia malayi is endemic to Kerala (most common), Assam, Orissa, Madhya Pradesh and West Bengal.

Brugia malayi are smaller in size compared to microfilaria of W. bancrofti. It shows kinks and secondary curves. Cephalic space is longer and carries double stylets at the anterior end. The nuclear column appears blurred in Giemsa-stained films. The tip of the tail carries 2 distinct nuclei, one terminal and the other subterminal.

The below image shows the microfilaria of Brugia malayi.

Other options:

Option A: The microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti is sheathed with a pointed tail tip free of nuclei.

Option C: The microfilariae of Loa loa is sheathed with nuclei extending up to the pointed tail tip.

Option D: The microfilariae of Onchocerca volvulus is unsheathed with a blunt tail tip free of nuclei.

Related Pearl: Filarial worms and their morphology
